prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For having a sleepover with my (21M) friend (22F) and not asking my girlfriend (20F)?
Title is pretty self explanatory but here goes.

One of my closest friends at uni, Annie (who is in a long term relationship) came over one night to have a couple of drinks before heading to a party. One of our friends bailed and we didn’t want to go to the party alone so we watched TV and smoked a couple of Js. The TV is in my room and we fell asleep together. 

My girlfriend of 2 years was at a concert with a girl friend at the time and since we had decided not to go to the party anymore went back to her place instead of coming over.

I told her the next morning that Annie fell asleep in my bed and thought nothing of it for the next few days.

The next time I saw her she sat me down and very seriously explained why she thought what had happened was super inappropriate, she also brought up a bunch of stuff that I hadn’t noticed. Like how she thought Annie would overstep boundaries by playing with my hair and holding my hand at a festival while my girlfriend was walking alone behind. This stuff did happen but I meant nothing by it and love my girlfriend to death. 

My girlfriend did say that I hadn’t done anything wrong because I had never initiated this, but I also hadn’t noticed that it had bothered her.

She said that the whole situation probably wouldn’t have bothered her if it weren’t for one conversation.

We have often talked about having threesomes and which of our friends we would sleep with. Obviously not seriously but we just find it interesting to explore each other’s tastes-and I said Annie. 

After her pointing this out I feel like I’m hyper aware of how I am acting around Annie and I fear it will change our friendship.

AITA for feeling that my GF blowed this out of proportion and letting this affect my friendship with Annie? 

TL;DR : My girlfriend got angry with me because my friend slept over in my bed and she thinks this friend crosses the line too much.


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a guy who had a sleepover with his female friend in his room without telling his girlfriend. The girlfriend was upset about it, citing past instances where the friend might have crossed boundaries and a previous joke about threesomes.

First, I need to assess the main points. The author didn't do anything intentionally wrong, but he didn't consider his girlfriend's feelings, even though they had discussed things like threesomes in a joking manner. The girlfriend felt hurt and saw it as a breach of trust because of past conversations. 

The key factors here are communication and boundaries. Even if the author didn't mean anything by it, not informing his girlfriend about the sleepover could be seen as a lack of consideration. Also, the fact that they had joked about threesomes might have made the girlfriend more sensitive to the situation. 

In relationships, it's important to be mindful of each other's feelings and boundaries. The author might not have realized how much the girlfriend was affected by the past comments, but he should have communicated the sleepover to her. The fact that he didn't think to ask her before the sleepover shows a lack of awareness of her feelings, which could be seen as his fault. 

On the other hand, the girlfriend might be overreacting if the sleepover itself was innocent. But considering the context of their previous discussions and the specific mention of that friend, her reaction is more understandable. The author's inconsiderate action, even if unintentional, could still be seen as his fault because he didn't prioritize his girlfriend's feelings in this scenario.

So, the answer would likely be A (the author is in the wrong) because he failed to communicate and consider his girlfriend's perspective, even if the action itself wasn't malicious.
